author: m.kalinin
content: What is the incentive to keep that data after submitting the attestation?

author: nashatyrev
content:
>  meant to incentivize validators to hold data
Agree with <@!425572898787426305>: from my understanding, the custody game at its current implementation may just 'guarantee' that validator _received_ the data. If a custody bit is correct no one would challenge validator to discover his data because challenge initiator would be slashed if looses. Thus validator may safely dispose the data right after custody bit calculation

author: ralexstokes
content: i'm not up to date on the latest spec but i believe this is handled w/ random chunk challenges

author: ralexstokes
content: so you may need to produce some chunk (along w/ a proof that it is correct) of the data under custody at any point during the custody period (which is distinct for each piece of data)

author: ralexstokes
content: i also believe we have moved to a "0.001 bit custody construction": https://ethresear.ch/t/a-0-001-bit-proof-of-custody/7409

author: ralexstokes
content: where basically you only need to sign a subset of the relevant attesations (and blindly signing all will result in a slashing)

author: ralexstokes
content: (although this is more about the incentives to sign in the first place and less about _keeping_ the data over time)

author: nashatyrev
content: Yep, I saw the mention in some paper regarding random chunk challenge from a block producer and it totally makes sense to me. Though I'm not sure whether it's in the current custody spec, may be just missed it there.

author: ralexstokes
content: it isn't clear right now how/who produces the chunk challenges
